user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_:
```c
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *hdr;

  mhd_assert (0 != header_len);
  mhd_assert (0 != content_len);
  if (NULL == (hdr = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header))))
    return false;

  hdr->header = header;
  hdr->header_size = header_len;
  hdr->value = content;
  hdr->value_size = content_len;
  hdr->kind = kind;
  _MHD_insert_header_last (response, hdr);

  return true; /* Success exit point */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
mhd_assert (0 != header_len);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No — the fragment itself does not introduce unreachable code under a normal assert implementation. Typically mhd_assert(condition) either (a) evaluates the condition and calls abort/assert-fail only when the condition is false, or (b) becomes a no-op in release builds; in both cases the subsequent code can be reached. A violation scenario would occur only if mhd_assert were defined to unconditionally exit or loop (for example, #define mhd_assert(x) abort(); or #define mhd_assert(x) for(;;); ), in which case the code after the macro would be unreachable.
